text: Frank Leibfarth: All right.
It is super exciting to be here.
Thank you, Paula, for a great talk,
and I'm really humbled to be in the presence of
the other members of the Talented 12,
both in the past and the future.
These are really special events,
so, thank you C&E News for putting it on.
So I'd like to talk to you today
about the work I'm doing in my lab and a little bit about
how I got here.
And when I found out about this award,
it kind of got me thinking a lot about,
why I am here, right?
Why am I doing what I'm doing?
Some of those more existential questions in life.
And if you asked me when I was growing up,
about the last thing I would have said I wanted to be,
was a scientist.
So, I've always had very diverse interests.
And I would say, kind of bringing together those
diverse interests and knowing that those diverse interests
can really be leveraged together to form my career,
has really brought me to this point.
So I grew up in South Dakota.
If you don't know where South Dakota is,
go to the middle of the country,
and then north.
It's quite cold.
But it's a state, also, of pretty diverse interests.
If you've heard of South Dakota,
or been to South Dakota,
you've probably heard of the western side of the state,
which has some really dramatic landscapes,
in terms of the Badlands National Park.
We have Mount Rushmore,
and we have a really beautiful Native American culture.
But I grew up in the more corn-growing side of the state.
We actually like corn so much,
we built a palace for it.
Which is at the top of the slide there,
the Corn Palace.
It has kind of your classic rolling fields of grain,
and I grew up in Yankton, South Dakota
on the Missouri River.
And in high school, again,
I had these two really diverse interests and passions,
neither of which were scientific.
I grew up really loving sports
and I grew up a competitive soccer player,
kind of playing around the country,
which eventually led to me being recruited to the football
team to be a kicker.
And, you know, through my teammates,
we ended up even winning
the state championship my senior year.
But I also had this, kind of, very different life
in high school, where I was really, really into theater.
I loved performing on stage.
I was in competitive one-act plays
every year in high school,
and even once I graduated,
I was in a touring theater company,
where we brought different musicals around the whole state.
But the one thing I wasn't interested in,
at the time,
was chemistry.
I actually had the opportunity to take an AP chemistry
class from a really great teacher in my high school,
and I said, "No, no, no,
I have these other interests that are more important."
So I went on to the University of South Dakota,
about 30 miles down the road.
A really good state school,
and I continued my pursuit as a student athlete.
Where I ended up graduating as the all-time leading scorer
at the University of South Dakota, as a kicker.
And I've think thinking about, kind of,
how those experiences shaped me, now--
playing football at that level
taught me two really important
lessons that I take with me every day,
one of which is accountability.
It was very clear when I missed a kick.
I was the only one that had the ability to do that.
But taking accountability for that, right?
Understanding that mistakes happen in life,
and being able to move forward from them,
productively, was really important.
And the second thing was to not fear failure.
So I had to be ready, as a kicker,
to go out and miss a game-winning field goal
before I could ever have the confidence to make one.
Right?
And I think that influences the problems my lab pursues
today, because, you know, we don't try to shoot lower
because it's a safer problem, right?
We wanna really not fear failure,
and go after those big challenges.
And, while playing football in college,
I also got my creative pursuit,
really, through research.
So this is when I discovered
how much joy you can have in research.
How I can get that creative outlet that I had in theater,
within research.
And I really owe my career to the NSF Research Experiences
for Undergraduates program,
where I got to get out of South Dakota
for one of the first times,
and move to the middle of Manhattan,
to Columbia University,
and participate in an REU there.
And then to the next summer at IBM.
And I continued on this diverse interest,
as I moved into my research career,
and have had really great mentors along the way,
including in my undergraduate time
with Jim Hedrick, a polymer scientist,
and Colin Nuckolls, who did organic chemistry.
To my really fabulous mentor, who I owe a lot to,
Craig Hawker at University at California, Santa Barbara,
a polymer chemist.
And I actually had the opportunity also,
to work with the professor Bongjin Moon
from Sogang University in Korea,
who was on sabbatical in Craig's group there.
And he was a really talented,
classically trained organic chemist.
And if you look closely in that picture,
there's another Talented 12 alumni, Luis Campos,
who joined me in a trip to Korea.
And then, in a really influential postdoc at MIT,
working in the lab of Tim Jamison,
but then getting to collaborate with Jeremiah Johnson
at the beginning of his career.
And it's these diverse interests that now, you know,
as opposed to when I was younger I kind of,
tried to keep those parts of my life separate.
Now I'm trying to embrace the diverse interests I have
in leading this research group.
And I wanted to put their pictures up front
because this is a super talented,
super enthusiastic group of people.
We try to maintain a really positive lab culture,
as Paula said,
and this makes going to work every day super, super fun.
So I'd like to talk to you a little bit about
the research we're pursuing.
So we work in the area of synthetic polymers,
what many of you may know better as plastics.
So plastics have had a positive impact
on almost every aspect of the modern world.
Most of our cars and airplanes are made of plastic,
which makes them tremendously lighter,
saving orders of magnitude of fuel in the process.
Plastic packaging in food keeps produce fresher, longer,
allowing us to feed more people in the same amount of
arable land,
and polymers are really important aspects
of biomedical devices.
There are over 12 polymer-drug conjugates
in the clinic today,
and they're really key pieces of orthopedic medical devices.
However, despite all the advantages of plastics,
they certainly have some disadvantages.
The majority of plastics are currently made from
petrochemical resources and their disposal,
or lack thereof,
is currently choking our environment and our oceans.
But this challenge stands in direct contrast to the fact
that a lot of the future needs we have
in our society remain material limited.
If we want really expansive solar energy
that is built on flexible substrates,
that is easy to install and access,
or if we want to create the next battery technology
that then will store all that energy,
we need continued innovations in synthetic materials.
The same could be said if we want to grow
an organ in a lab or a tissue,
we need to recapitulate the complexities of the
extracellular matrix in a synthetic material.
So, as we move forward with material design,
we really only have one choice.
The materials have to be both sustainable and functional.
We can't have this either-or approach
to material design anymore.
So it's clear that the materials of today
will not solve tomorrow's challenges.
And as somebody who's interested in organic synthesis,
right, this might be a bit biased,
but I contend that the way we make materials today
will not be the way to solve tomorrow's challenges.
So we need to really develop fundamental innovations
in how we make these polymers,
in order to move towards a time where we're making
both sustainable and functional materials.
And I contend, and I'll tell you about,
how I think polymers' stereochemistry
will play a large role in that.
So to think about the influence of stereochemistry
in polymers,
I ask you to consider the difference
between cellulose and starch.
Cellulose is a structural material in plants
that we use for paper and cotton.
Starch is an important part of our diet
found in grains and potatoes.
However, both these biopolymers
are chemically identical polymers of glucose.
They differ only in one stereocenter per repeat unit
and that gives them these drastically different
material properties.
So the same can be said of synthetic polymers,
and this was really pointed out by Giulio Natta in 1955,
when he discovered how to control the stereochemistry
of polypropylene.
So atactic polypropylene,
where you don't control the stereochemistry,
is an effectively useless viscous liquid.
However, isotactic polypropylene,
when all you do is you take that same material,
and control the stereochemistry,
this is the second-most important polymer in the world,
made at over 50 million tons annually,
used in everything from high-strength fibers,
to packaging,
to the bumper of your car.
So this is the dramatic difference that stereochemistry
can have in polymers.
So why don't we take sustainable materials
and use the methods that are used for polypropylene
to control their stereochemistry?
Well there's a fundamental limitation.
So, we control the stereochemistry of polypropylene,
and other α-olefins
by coordination insertion polymerization.
And the key here is, that as you're growing this long,
polymer chain,
the end group is always attached to a metal center.
Thus, you can control ligand geometry
around that metal center.
That will control facial addition of the next monomers
and stereochemistry.
However, if you add even a small amount of any polar
or more-functional group,
such as this Lewis basic heteroatom,
that will irreversibly bind
to these early transition metal catalysts,
and you'll get no polymer out.
So this has been the fundamental limitation
for over 60 years that has impeded progress.
And what this means, really,
is coordination insertion polymerization
is kind of a synthetic method made
for petrochemical resources, right?
If we want to move to incorporating building blocks
from things like corn, mint, and trees,
right, biology loves to oxidize things,
so we have lots of these Lewis basic heteroatoms
that we need to create methods to be able to access.
So because coordination insertion polymerization
only works for these hydrophobic monomers,
we usually polymerize more functional materials.
I show here a vinyl ether through ionic polymerization.
In ionic polymerization,
you don't have a metal bound to the chain end.
You have this achiral reactive intermediate
where the next monomer can attack on either face
of this intermediate,
giving you atactic polymers.
So our central hypothesis,
when I started my group,
was, we can't bind a metal center to this chain end,
but what if we can take advantage of this counterion?
And by creating a chiral counterion,
we control the stereochemical environment
at the end group of that polymer
and thus, bias facial addition of each incoming monomer.
And again, my diverse interests and the skill set I gained
during my PHD and Postdoc really helped with this,
because I was able to look at the tools
of small molecule organic chemistry
and asymmetric ion-pairing catalysis,
and see these BINOL-derived phosphoric acids
as a really privileged scaffold
to be able to leverage this type of idea.
If you look back at this literature,
you actually see building blocks that we'd like
to make polymers from,
reported to undergo highly stereoselective reactions.
So I won't give you, kind of, all the gory details
but in summary,
we were able to demonstrate this concept
with one chiral counterion.
I show here the polymerization of vinyl ethers
to isotactic polyvinyl ethers with 88-93% stereoselectivity
depending on that R group.
And for each of these,
this is the highest stereoselectivity reported to date.
And imparting stereochemistry
gave us the emergent physical properties
that we were looking for.
So what's shown on your left is typical polyvinyl ethers
that are atactic,
where you don't control the stereochemistry.
What's shown on the right is the use of our chiral anion
to control the stereochemistry,
gives you these really nice semicrystalline thermoplastics.
And I really like this picture because those two materials
are chemically identical polymers,
they're simply stereoisomers of each other,
and you can see the emergent physical properties
that provides.
And, to kind of quantitate those physical properties,
what we can do is we can take that material,
we can press it into a film,
and we can pull on it 'til it breaks,
and see what kind of response we get.
And what I show you here is,
the black dotted line there is actually a polyethylene
material we bought from Dow Chemical.
So that's a commercial polymer made at really large scale
and our material has effectively
the same exact mechanical properties
as that commercial material.
But the nice thing,
because we're able to now impart functionality
into our polymer by controlling stereochemistry
via this ionic polymerization,
our material actually has adhesion properties
to glass and other polar materials,
that are 14 times better
than that Dow commercial polyethylene.
So by using this chiral counterion approach,
we were able to make materials that you might recognize,
but actually have emergent properties,
such as adhesion.
Also I told you quickly about, you know,
how we developed this method,
to create novel materials
and are able to do structure-property studies,
and I would say in many ways,
this is kind of the way in which my group works.
So moving forward, right,
we don't want to kind of stop at vinyl ethers,
we want to see if this conceptual approach
could be applicable to multiple classes of polymers
and really make this a platform method.
So one of the first things we're doing with vinyl ethers is,
can we expand the substrate scope?
And again,
now that we can use much more functional monomers,
can those building blocks actually be made
from biorenewable resources--
again, things we get from sugar or fermentation or trees.
And can incorporating functional handles into this polymer
actually give you sites to kind of do a retrosynthetic
depolymerization of these materials?
So not only are we making them from renewable resources,
but then we can actually break them down
and repolymerize some of these materials
to move towards a more sustainable plastics economy.
And, I think this will work beyond vinyl ethers also,
so again, this larger scale conceptual approach
can hopefully develop emergent properties
from a whole variety of building blocks
that we've kind of thought did a certain function
without stereocontrol.
And, of course, the overall goal
is really to make an impact here, right?
The polymer industry is absolutely massive
and if we can shift more and more of that industry
towards sustainable materials,
as you can see,
it's a pretty small slice there.
I think we can have an impact,
and I think stereocontrol will actually give
these sustainable polymers the properties
that consumers want to use
and I think that'll be the first step
in bringing that to life.
(applause)
